tit.e: Tael (A Former Japanese Weight Unit, And Also A Former Japanese And Chinese Currency Unit)
Ryo (A Former Japanese Weight Unit, And Also A Former Japanese And Chinese Currency Unit)
Ryo (A Former Japanese Weight Unit, And Also A Former Japanese And Chinese Currency Unit)

sen.j: 両（りょう）は、尺貫法における質量の単位であり、また、近世の日本における金貨、および中国における秤量銀貨の通貨単位である。
sen.e: Tael served as a weight unit in the traditional East Asian system of weights and measures, and also served as a currency unit both in Japan and in China - in Japan, the unit of gold coins in the early modern ages, and in China, the unit of "hyoryo ginka" (silver coin used as currency by weight).
sen.cmt: （注①）・・・「尺貫法」は狭義では日本における度量衡の単位系を指し、広義では東アジア一帯で用いられる度量衡の単位系を指します。このファイルの以下の内容から、ここの「両」が中国の質量単位としてのそれを含んでいることは明らかであり、従って「尺貫法」も広義に用いているように思われます。（注②）・・・「秤量（ひょうりょう）銀貨」の定訳は見つかりませんでしたが、「秤量貨幣」の研究社・大和英の訳（currency by weight)を参考に"silver coin used as currency by weight"としました。
sen.e: Ryo served as a weight unit in the traditional East Asian system of weights and measures, and also served as a currency unit in Japan and in China; in Japan, the unit of gold coins in the early modern ages, and in China, the unit of hyoryo ginka (silver coin used as currency by weight).

Ryo served as a weight unit in the traditional East Asian system of weights and measures, and also served as a currency unit in Japan and in China; in Japan, the unit of gold coins in the early modern ages, and in China, the unit of hyoryo ginka (silver coin used as currency by weight).

sen.j: 質量の単位としての両は、匁の倍量（貫、斤の分量）単位で、日本では1両＝10匁＝1/100貫＝1/16斤とされた。
sen.e: As a weight unit, tael had a larger scale than "monme" (former Japanese weight unit) and a smaller scale than "kan" and "kin" (kan and kin were both fomer Japanese weight units), and in Japan, 1 tael, 10 monme, 0.01 kan, and a sixteenth kin were equalized.

As a weight unit, ryo had a heavier scale than monme (former Japanese weight unit) and a lighter scale than kan and kin (kan and kin were both former Japanese weight units), and in Japan, 1 ryo, 10 monme, 0.01 kan, and a 16th kin were equalized.

As a weight unit, ryo had a heavier scale than monme (former Japanese weight unit) and a lighter scale than kan and kin (kan and kin were both former Japanese weight units), and in Japan, 1 ryo, 10 monme, 0.01 kan, and a 16th kin were equalized.

sen.j: 奈良時代に公布された大宝律令では隋代（唐代初期か）の一両に準じて、おおむね41～42グラムくらいであったが、唐代になり11%程度減少し37.3グラムとなり、日本国内でもこれに近い値となった。
sen.e: Under the Taiho Code promulgated in the Nara period, the weight of 1 tael was set around 41- 42 grams, following the standard of the Sui dynasty (or the early stage of the Tang dynasty) China, and when the weight of 1 tael was reduced by around 11% into 37.3 grams in Tang dynasty China, Japan followed China again and took almost the same standard.

Under the Taiho Code promulgated in the Nara period, the weight of 1 ryo was set around 41to 42 grams, following the standard of the Sui Dynasty (or the early Tang Dynasty) China, and when the weight of 1 ryo was reduced by around 11 percents into 37.3 grams in Tang Dynasty, Japan followed China again and took almost the same standard.

Under the Taiho Code promulgated in the Nara period, the weight of 1 ryo was set around 41to 42 grams, following the standard of the Sui Dynasty (or the early Tang Dynasty) China, and when the weight of 1 ryo was reduced by around 11 percents into 37.3 grams in Tang Dynasty, Japan followed China again and took almost the same standard.

sen.j: 明治時代以降、日本国内ではほとんど使用されていない。
sen.e: From the Meiji period, tael as the weight unit has rarely been used in Japan.
After the Meiji period, ryo as the weight unit has rarely been used in Japan.
After the Meiji period, ryo as the weight unit has rarely been used in Japan.

sen.j: 現代の中国の1市両は50グラムである。
sen.e: In today's China, 1 shi liang is set at 50 grams.
In today's China, 1 ryo (liang in Chinese) is set at 50 grams.
In today's China, 1 ryo (liang in Chinese) is set at 50 grams.

sen.j: 金貨の通貨単位としての両は武田信玄により、鋳造を命じられた甲州金により確立され、江戸幕府に継承されたもので、1両は4分に等しく、また16朱に等しい。
sen.e: As the currency unit of gold coins, tael was established when Shingen TAKEDA adopted it for "Koshu-kin" (the gold coin minted in Koshu Province), and it took root when Edo "bakufu" (Japanese feudal regime headed by a shogun) also adopted it, and Shingen and Edo bakufu equalized 1 tael with 4 "bu," and also equalized 1 tael with 16 "shu" (bu and shu were former Japanese currency unit).

As the currency unit of gold coins, ryo was established by Koshu-kin (the gold coin minted in Koshu Province), which Shingen TAKEDA ordered to coin, and handed down to the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun); 1 ryo was equalized with 4 bu, or 16 shu (bu and shu were former Japanese currency unit).
sen.cmt: 統一リストに合わせ、用語を変更しました。
sen.e: As the currency unit of gold coins, ryo was established by Koshu-kin (the gold coin minted in Koshu Province), which Shingen TAKEDA ordered to coin, and handed down to the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun); 1 ryo was equalized with 4 bu, or 16 shu (bu and shu were former Japanese currency unit).

sen.j: 小判1枚の貨幣価値に相当し、したがって二分金2枚に、一分金、一分銀4枚に相当し、また二朱金、南鐐二朱銀8枚に、一朱金、一朱銀16枚に相当する。
sen.e: 1 "koban" (former Japanese gold coin of oval shape) had the currency value of 1 tael, and 1 koban could be exchanged into various other coins, that is, 2 "nibu-kin" (former Japanese gold coin of 2 bu), 4 "ichibu-kin" (former Japanese gold coin of 1 bu), 4 "ichibu-gin" (former Japanese silver coin of 1 bu), 8 "nishu-kin" (former Japanese gold coin of 2 shu), 8 "Nanryo nishu-gin" (former Japanese silver coin of 2 shu), 16 "isshu-kin" (former Japanese gold coin of 1 shu), and 16 "isshu-gin" (former Japanese silver coin of 1 shu).

1 ryo had currency value as 1 koban (former Japanese gold coin of oval shape) which 1 ryo was equivalent to 2 nibu-kin (former Japanese gold coin of 2 bu), 4 ichibu-kin (former Japanese gold coin of 1 bu) or ichibu-gin (former Japanese silver coin of 1 bu), 8 nishu-kin (former Japanese gold coin of 2 shu) or Nanryo nishu-gin (former Japanese silver coin of 2 shu), 16 isshu-kin (former Japanese gold coin of 1 shu) or isshu-gin (former Japanese silver coin of 1 shu) accordingly.

1 ryo had currency value as 1 koban (former Japanese gold coin of oval shape) which 1 ryo was equivalent to 2 nibu-kin (former Japanese gold coin of 2 bu), 4 ichibu-kin (former Japanese gold coin of 1 bu) or ichibu-gin (former Japanese silver coin of 1 bu), 8 nishu-kin (former Japanese gold coin of 2 shu) or Nanryo nishu-gin (former Japanese silver coin of 2 shu), 16 isshu-kin (former Japanese gold coin of 1 shu) or isshu-gin (former Japanese silver coin of 1 shu) accordingly.

sen.j: 明治時代に通貨単位として円 (通貨)（円）が導入されたが、切り替え時に「1圓は1両と等価」とされ、しばらくの間は「圓」のことを「両」とも呼んでいた。
sen.e: In the Meiji period, "yen" was introduced as the currency unit, and when the exchange rate among currencies was changed, 1 yen and 1 tael were equalized, so yen was used as the synonym of tael for a while.
In the Meiji period, yen was introduced as the currency unit, however, '1 yen was equivalent to 1 ryo' in changeover phase, so 'yen' was called 'ryo' for a while.
In the Meiji period, yen was introduced as the currency unit, however, '1 yen was equivalent to 1 ryo' in changeover phase, so 'yen' was called 'ryo' for a while.

sen.j: また江戸時代にも文政年間頃から「両」のことを俗称として「圓」と呼ぶ習慣が一部にあったという。
sen.e: And from around the Bunsei era (A.D. 1818 - 1830) in the Edo period, there were some areas where "yen" was custmarily used as the popular name of tael, they say.
And from around the Bunsei era (1818 to 1830) in the Edo period, it is said some called 'yen' as 'ryo' habitually.
And from around the Bunsei era (1818 to 1830) in the Edo period, it is said some called 'yen' as 'ryo' habitually.

sen.j: 質量の単位としての両は、古代中国で生まれたものである。
sen.e: Tael as the weight unit originated in ancient China.
Ryo as the weight unit originated in ancient China.
Ryo as the weight unit originated in ancient China.

sen.j: 漢代では『漢書律歴志』に下記のような記述がある。
sen.e: Treatise on rhythm and calendar in Book of Han, written in Han dynasty China, says as follows :
"Book of Han, Treatise on rhythm and the calendar" in Han Dynasty says as follows:
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせ、用語を変更しました。
sen.e: "Book of Han, Treatise on rhythm and the calendar" in Han Dynasty says as follows:

sen.j: 「権者銖・両・斤・鈞・石 (単位)也。」
sen.e: "The units of weight are 'shu' (in pinyin, 'zhu'), 'tael,' 'kin' (in pinyin, 'jin'), 'kin' (in pinyin, 'jun'), and 'koku' (in pinyin, 'dan')."
sen.cmt: （注①）・・・翻訳者は原文を「権（はか）る者は、銖・両・斤・鈞・石なり」と読み下した上、「物の重さを測る単位は、銖・両・斤・鈞・石である。」の意味に解しています。（注②）・・・「銖・両・斤・鈞・石」のそれぞれにつき、中国の単位であることもありピンイン（中国語読みのローマ字表記）を併せ記しておきました。
sen.e: The units of weight are shu (in pinyin, 'zhu'), ryo, kin (in pinyin, 'jin'), kin (in pinyin, 'jun'), and koku (in pinyin, 'dan').'
sen.cmt: 表記、用語を変更しました。
sen.e: The units of weight are shu (in pinyin, 'zhu'), ryo, kin (in pinyin, 'jin'), kin (in pinyin, 'jun'), and koku (in pinyin, 'dan').'

sen.j: 「所以称物平施知軽重也。」
sen.e: "By diffusing the units, the weight of things can be known."
sen.cmt: （注）・・・翻訳者は原文を「物を称する所以（ゆえん）を平（たいら）に施（し）き、軽重を知るなり。」と読み下した上、「物（の重さ）を呼称する手段を広く行き渡らせることで、（物質の）重さを知ることが出来る。」の意味に解しています。
sen.e: By diffusing the units, the weight of things can be known.'
By diffusing the units, the weight of things can be known.'

sen.j: 「本起於黄鍾之重。」
sen.e: "Originally, the name of shu came from the weight of the proso millet grains that are fully put into 'kosho pipe' (a kind of flute)."
sen.cmt: （注）・・・翻訳者は原文を「本（もと）は黄鍾（こうしょう）の重さより起こる。」と読み下した上、「（銖の単位は）もともと黄鍾管（の中に入る黍）の重さが起源である。」の意味に解しています。
sen.e: Originally, the name of shu came from the weight of the proso millet grains that are fully put into Kosho pipe, a kind of flute.'
Originally, the name of shu came from the weight of the proso millet grains that are fully put into Kosho pipe, a kind of flute.'

sen.j: 「一龠容千二百黍重十二銖。」
sen.e: "The volume of kosho pipe (= 1 'yaku') is the same as the volume of 1200 proso millet grains, whose weight is 12 shu."
sen.cmt: （注）・・・翻訳者は原文を「一龠（ひとやく）は千二百の黍（きび）を容（い）れ、重（ちょう）は十二銖。」と読み下した上、「一龠（ひとやく）の黄鍾管の中に黍の粒1200個が入るが、その重量は12銖である。」の意味に解しています。
sen.e: The volume of kosho pipe (= 1 'yaku') is the same as the volume of 1200 proso millet grains, whose weight is 12 shu.'
The volume of kosho pipe (= 1 'yaku') is the same as the volume of 1200 proso millet grains, whose weight is 12 shu.'

sen.j: 「両之為両。」
sen.e: "And twice the 12 shu is set equal to 1 tael."
sen.cmt: （注）・・・翻訳者は原文を「之（これ）を両して両となす」と読み下した上、「これを二つ合わせて1両とする。」の意味に解しています。
sen.e: And twice the 12 shu is set equal to 1 ryo.'
And twice the 12 shu is set equal to 1 ryo.'

sen.j: 黄鍾管の体積が一龠部（やく）であり、これに入る黍1200粒を12銖（しゅ。朱はこれの略字）とし、これを二つ合わせた質量すなわち24銖を1両とした。
sen.e: In short, the volume of an kosho pipe (= 1 yaku) is the same as the volume of 1200 proso millet grains, and the weight of the 1200 grains was set equal to 12 銖 (朱 in abbreviation [both read as "shu"]), and twice the 12 shu, or 24 shu, was set equal to 1 tael.

In short, the volume of an kosho pipe (= 1 yaku) is the same as the volume of 1200 proso millet grains, and the weight of the 1200 grains was set equal to 12 shu (銖; 朱 in abbreviation), and twice the 12 shu, or 24 shu, was set equal to 1 ryo.

In short, the volume of an kosho pipe (= 1 yaku) is the same as the volume of 1200 proso millet grains, and the weight of the 1200 grains was set equal to 12 shu (銖; 朱 in abbreviation), and twice the 12 shu, or 24 shu, was set equal to 1 ryo.

sen.j: 「両」の漢字には「二つ」という意味がある。
sen.e: Incidentally, the Chinese character of 両 (reads as tael) has the second meaning of "twice."
Incidentally, the Chinese character of '両' (reads as ryo) has the second meaning of 'two.'
Incidentally, the Chinese character of '両' (reads as ryo) has the second meaning of 'two.'

sen.j: この両は3銭8分程度（銭は日本の匁と同じ）である。
sen.e: Here, 1 tael was roughly equal to 3 sen (also called monme in Japan) plus 8 bu.
Here, 1 ryo was roughly equal to 3 sen (also called monme in Japan) and 8 bu.
Here, 1 ryo was roughly equal to 3 sen (also called monme in Japan) and 8 bu.

sen.j: 唐代にこれの3倍を大両とする制度ができたが、大両は3銭8分の3倍（11銭4分）である。
sen.e: Under the Tang dynasty China, the new weight unit "larger tael" was made, and 1 larger tael weighs 11 sen plus 4 bu, which is three times as much as 1 tael.
sen.cmt: （注①）一原文一訳文の例外対処（注②）原文の「唐代」は「隋代」の誤りではないでしょうか。
sen.e: Under the Tang Dynasty, the system of larger ryo, which was three times larger than ryo, was established that larger ryo weighed 11 sen and 4 bu, which was three times as much as 3 sen and 8 bu.
Under the Tang Dynasty, the system of larger ryo, which was three times larger than ryo, was established that larger ryo weighed 11 sen and 4 bu, which was three times as much as 3 sen and 8 bu.

sen.j: 後の唐代に「斤」、「両」の質量が縮小し、開元通宝が1/10両の基準で鋳造されたため、10銭（匁）と等しいとされるようになった。
sen.e: And later in Tang dynasty, the weight standard of kin and larger tael was reduced, and 1 larger tael and 10 sen (or 10 monme) became equal in currency value when "Kaigen Tsuho" ('Kai Yuan Tong Bao' in pinyin, a coin of the Tang dynasty China) was minted at the weight of a tenth of 1 larger tael.
sen.cmt: （注①）・・・一原文一訳文の例外対処（注②）・・・「開元通宝」は中国の貨幣ゆえピンインも表記しておきました。（注③）・・・多少質量が縮小して10銭と等しいとされた「1両」は内容的に見て「大両」の方の「1両」だと解されます。
sen.e: And later in Tang Dynasty, the weight standard of 'kin' and 'ryo' was reduced and Kaigen Tsuho ('Kai Yuan Tong Bao' in pinyin, a coin of the Tang Dynasty China) was minted at the weight of a 10th of 1 ryo which was equivalent to 10 sen (or 10 monme).

And later in Tang Dynasty, the weight standard of 'kin' and 'ryo' was reduced and Kaigen Tsuho ('Kai Yuan Tong Bao' in pinyin, a coin of the Tang Dynasty China) was minted at the weight of a 10th of 1 ryo which was equivalent to 10 sen (or 10 monme).

sen.j: 日本にも両方の「両」が伝わった。
sen.e: Both units of smaller tael and larger tael were introduced into Japan.
Both 'ryo,' smaller ryo and larger ryo, were introduced into Japan.
Both 'ryo,' smaller ryo and larger ryo, were introduced into Japan.

sen.j: 嘉量による1両は『漢書律歴志』の記述に基づく実測の結果は14.167グラムであり、これは「小両」に相当する。
sen.e: When we weigh 1 tael with the measure of the Xin dynasty China, based on the depiction in Treatise on rhythm and calendar in Book of Han, it is 14.167 grams, which suggests 1 tael here implies 1 smaller tael.
sen.cmt: （注①）・・・一原文一訳文の例外対処。（注②）・・・「嘉量」は「中国新代の計測器」と訳しています。
sen.e: When we weigh 1 ryo with chia-liang standard measure in "Book of Han, Treatise on rhythm and the calendar," actual measured value was 14.167 grams which equivalent to 1 'smaller ryo.'
sen.cmt: 表現を変え、用語を変更しました。
sen.e: When we weigh 1 ryo with chia-liang standard measure in "Book of Han, Treatise on rhythm and the calendar," actual measured value was 14.167 grams which equivalent to 1 'smaller ryo.'

sen.j: 呉承洛の『中国度量衡史』による隋代の1両は41.762グラムであり嘉量の約3倍、唐代の1両は37.301グラムであり、「大両」に相当する。
sen.e: And when we weigh 1 tael with the standard of Sui dynasty China, based on the depiction in History of Chinese Weights and Measures (written by Wu Chengluo), it is 41.762 grams - about three times as much as the above-mentioned weight in Xin dynasty - and with the standard of the Tang dynasty China, 1 tael weighs at 37.301 grams, which suggests this 1 tael implies 1 larger tael.
sen.cmt: （注）一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: And when we weigh 1 ryo with the standard of Sui Dynasty China in "History of Chinese Weights and Measures," written by Wu Chengluo, the value was 41.762 grams, which was about three times as much as the previously-mentioned weight with chia-liang, and with the standard of the Tang Dynasty, 1 ryo weighed at 37.301 grams which equivalent to 1 'larger ryo.'
sen.cmt: 表現を変え、用語を変更しました。
sen.e: And when we weigh 1 ryo with the standard of Sui Dynasty China in "History of Chinese Weights and Measures," written by Wu Chengluo, the value was 41.762 grams, which was about three times as much as the previously-mentioned weight with chia-liang, and with the standard of the Tang Dynasty, 1 ryo weighed at 37.301 grams which equivalent to 1 'larger ryo.'

sen.j: 江戸時代初期までは、この唐代の「両」が日本に伝えられ用いられていたが、寛文元年（1661年）に度量衡の「衡」が統一された。
sen.e: The Tang dynasty's larger tael was introduced into Japan and was used as the weight unit until the early Edo period, and in A.D. 1661, the Japanese weight units were standardized.
sen.cmt: （注）一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: This Tang Dynasty's 'ryo' was introduced into Japan to be used until the early Edo period, then in 1661, the Japanese weight units were standardized.
This Tang Dynasty's 'ryo' was introduced into Japan to be used until the early Edo period, then in 1661, the Japanese weight units were standardized.

sen.j: 以後、両替商で用いられる分銅は後藤四郎兵衛家のみ製作が許され、これ以外のものの製作および使用は不正を防止するため厳禁とされた。
sen.e: And thereafter, Shirobei GOTO and his descendants monopolized the production right of "fundo" (counterweight) used at an exchange house, and the production and use of other kinds of fundo was prohibited strictly for the prevention of illegal exchange.
sen.cmt: （注）一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: And thereafter, Shirobei GOTO family was only allowed to produce fundo (counterweight) used at an exchange house, and the production and use of other kinds of fundo was prohibited strictly for the prevention of illegal exchange.

And thereafter, Shirobei GOTO family was only allowed to produce fundo (counterweight) used at an exchange house, and the production and use of other kinds of fundo was prohibited strictly for the prevention of illegal exchange.

sen.j: この分銅は「両」を基本単位としている。
sen.e: The basic weight unit of the fundo was tael.
The basic weight unit of the fundo was 'ryo.'
The basic weight unit of the fundo was 'ryo.'

sen.j: ただし秤量銀貨の通貨単位は、小判の通貨単位の「両」との混同を避ける意味から「匁」および「貫」が用いられた。
sen.e: However, it was "monme" and "kan" that were adopted as the currency unit for hyoryo ginka, lest the term "tael" should be confused with the tael used as the currency unit of koban.
However, to avoid mixing up 'ryo' of the currency unit for koban, 'monme' and 'kan' were used as the currency unit for hyoryo ginka.
However, to avoid mixing up 'ryo' of the currency unit for koban, 'monme' and 'kan' were used as the currency unit for hyoryo ginka.

sen.j: すなわち、肆兩（しりょう）の分銅と釣合う丁銀は銀40匁と表した。
sen.e: In other words, when "chogin" (the silver coin used as the currency by weight) was balanced with 4 tael of fundo, the chogin's currency value was depicted as 40 monme of silver.
sen.cmt: （注①）・・・「肆兩（しりょう）」は「四両」の当て字です。（注②）・・・「丁銀」は秤量銀貨として用いられた銀貨のことです。
sen.e: In other words, when chogin (the silver coin used as the currency by weight) was balanced with 4 ryo of fundo, the chogin's currency value was equivalent to 40 monme of silver.
In other words, when chogin (the silver coin used as the currency by weight) was balanced with 4 ryo of fundo, the chogin's currency value was equivalent to 40 monme of silver.

sen.j: 江戸時代の1両は分銅の実測によると37.46から37.47グラム程度である。
sen.e: By measuring the fundo, we know that the weight of 1 tael in the Edo period was around 37.46 - 37. 47 grams.
By an actual measured value of the fundo, 1 ryo in the Edo period was around 37.46 to 37.47 grams.
By an actual measured value of the fundo, 1 ryo in the Edo period was around 37.46 to 37.47 grams.

sen.j: 一方中国では秤量銀貨の実測値一両（大両）を銀一両（銀両）と表した。
sen.e: Meanwhile in China, 1 larger tael, measured with hyoryo ginka, was depicted as 1 tael of silver.
Meanwhile in China, 1 ryo (larger ryo) with actual measured value of hyoryo ginka was equivalent to 1 ryo of silver (ginryo).

sen.j: 一方江戸幕府は御定相場として慶長14年（1609年）に、金1両は、銀50匁（約187グラム）、銭4貫文（4,000文 (通貨単位)）に等価と布告し、後の元禄13年（1700年）に、金1両は、銀60匁（約225グラム）、銭4貫文と改正した。
sen.e: Meanwhile, Edo bakufu set the mint par of exchange, proclaiming in A.D. 1609 that 1 tael of gold should be equalized in value with 50 monme of silver, which weighed about 187 grams, and with 4 kanmon (= 4000 mon) of copper, and later in A.D. 1700, Edo bakufu proclaimed again that 1 tael of gold should be equalized with 60 monme of silver, which weighed about 225 grams, and with 4 kanmon of copper.

sen.e: For, the value of 1 tael varied from time to time - for example, the value of 1 tael in the Keicho era was higher in a digit or more than that in the last days of the Tokugawa shogunate when currency value fell dramatically - and moreover, as life style in the Edo period was completely different from that today, the value of 1 tael varies greatly depending on what criterion (the price level or the wage level) is chosen - and depending on what items are chosen for the example of the price level.
